text: Yesterday evening I spoke about what I like to call the fundamental theorem, the whole aspect of liberation, one way to look at it, which could be described as was described in medieval Christianity by a single word, simplificatio, simplification, a tremendous complexity of our ordinary experiences reduced to the simplicity of our spiritual source. Simplex in Latin means single fold, one fold. The thing that is one is the nothing, the very special nothing, that is the union of all the somethings, all the affirmations and negations, contains within it all of life and all of death activity. So we could describe that process of simplification as learning how to be completely alive, learning how to be completely dead. That's the paradoxical characteristic of a liberated person. It's sometimes described in the literature of Zen as an enlightened person is described poetically as eyes like burning embers inside a dry skull. If that doesn't make any sense now, it will for many of you with time, completely alive, completely dead. The first time I ever walked into a Zen meditation hall, it was in Japan, and this is what was inscribed on the plaque at the entrance. You may not be able to see from the distance, even if you can, only Philip can read it. But it says, life, death, fathom these. Fathom these, like research these, understand these. Shansu, kyuju, Japanese shoji, kore wo kiwame yo. And that was pretty startling. And I've come to realize that yes, indeed, that is a way that we could describe this. Freud, at the end of his career, said there's nothing but thanatos and eros. Thanatos is the Greek for death, eros is, of course, the same root as erotic, but he took it as the life principle, the affirming. So, thanatos, eros, theorema basica, and I wrote it in Greek, the Greek equivalent of this. As we're meditating, we come to understand that the complexity of experience is really the simplicity of our senses, and the simplicity of our senses is the further simplicity of energy flow, and that energy flow ultimately can be analyzed into effortless expansion and contraction. So we experience that which we call life from a human perspective, and that's which we call death from a human perspective. We come to realize are merely reflections of these deeper effortless principles. And as we practice giving ourselves back to our parents, we become intimate with the life and death forces, and we become the life and death forces. And to that extent, we become immortal. Not in the sense that we live forever, necessarily, but in the sense that we become life and death itself, which is, this pair is unending in their creative activity, their molding activity. In the Jewish mystical tradition, chesed ve'gvura, chesed, the affirming side of God, gvura, the limiting side, this is how the Kabbalah describes be'ri'ay, ye'sh, me'ayin, the continuous creation of ye'sh, selves, and things. Ye'sh means both self and a thing. Me'ayin, from the divine nothingness. It was understood in that tradition. So what we humans call thanatos and eros are reflections of these deeper principles. So by fathoming what we humans call thanatos and eros, we can understand these deep principles. Conversely, when we understand these deep principles, we're not so freaked out by death and sexuality, thanatos and eros. Do you think sex is dirty? I do. For most people, for the great majority of human beings, sex is quite dirty. Now, that doesn't mean for a minute that I think that sex is dirt. That's quite a different thing. Dirty. Why dirty? Well, something's dirty if it's covered over. It's covered over with something that doesn't let you see what it really is. So we have the habits of craving, a relationship to pleasure that prevents pleasure from being complete and therefore prevents pleasure from yielding true satisfaction. That's a kind of dirt. Pleasure isn't dirt. Pure pleasure purifies. Pleasure is the effortless vibration of the Source. But because of our habits of not knowing how to experience pure pleasure, in general pleasure is covered with the dirt of congealing, taking the form either of not letting the pleasure pass instant by instant, or taking the form of tightening upon its arising instant by instant, or taking both forms, but preventing pleasure from being an effortless contact with the spiritual Source. And since eroticism, lovemaking, our amorous encounters, our relationships, the romantic side of our being, is for most people the most pleasurable, it is also the most dirty. And then people get very confused because they think that there's something wrong with the eroticism itself. Like saying that there's something wrong with the gold statue because it's got soot on it. And it is very interesting, the confusion that we see in human languages. For example, just as there's a very common confusion between pain and suffering, there's a very common confusion between pleasure and craving. You can see it clearly in two West Germanic languages, English and German. In German, Lust means pleasure, and in English it means lust. Those are two very, very different critters. Very different critters indeed. Lust is the dirt on Lust. The dirt on Lust. Our job is to gradually train away that dirt, clean away that dirt. There's another kind of dirt on sex, on consciousness, that prevents us from understanding what it's all really about. At its core, what is the jewel in the lotus? What's the treasure inside that flower? As we become clearer about oneness and separateness, how the sense of self arises, how the sense of self disappears into merging, then we understand what's at the core of that experience. The dissolution of the boundary between inside and outside, but under a very special circumstance. Yet the mechanism by which the boundary between inside and outside dissolves in that circumstance is identical to the mechanism by which it can dissolve under any circumstance with any object, from a saint to a garbage can, and a fortiori with one's lover. So as we get clearer and clearer and learn, retrain our relationship to pleasure, then Eros becomes cleaner and cleaner, and closer and closer to the divine Eros. In other words, direct spiritual experience, enlightenment itself. In most cultures, people have some uneasiness about Eros, and I think it's because consciously or unconsciously, some part of our being knows, in most cases it doesn't deliver what we think it should deliver. And that's right. Each experience should fundamentally change our consciousness permanently, each one. Each one is meant to be the equivalent of the other. Each experience is meant to be the equivalent of a two-week retreat in terms of insight and purification. Yet it doesn't seem to yield that. So whether you say it's an energy let down, or whether it's a guilt, or whether it's a this or that, something's not quite what we would like it to be. But it can be, and it should be. So we do a lot of work in these retreats with transcending pain. It carries over into deepening fulfillment with pleasure. There are whole paths, of course, built around Eros. It's good if it's real, but it's just as hard as the real. If it's real, but it's just as hard as the path built around pain. Maybe harder in some ways. So it's a matter of what's suited to what person. So as we really fathom Eros, really fathom that side of things, we'll come to understand, come to clean away the unskillful experience of each of those thousands of waves and wavelets of pleasure, so that each one of those thousands of waves and wavelets of pleasure will be an earth-shaking experience, literally, not just metaphorically. You know how they say you haven't made love unless the whole room shakes? Each time the whole room shakes means one wavelet of pleasure was complete. That pleasure did not need to exist as an object anymore. So it was, as the cliche goes, bigger than both of us, considerably bigger than both of us. That's the impermanence, the cosmic shiver. So fathom Eros. Many of us will be returning to some Eros after the retreat. Fathom Eros. And some of us will be returning to facing Thanatos. In fact, all of us eventually will, in our friends, as you get older. That's one of the things I've certainly started to notice, more and more people in my life passing away. We have to fathom Thanatos also. There's two really deep arts, Ars Amandi and Ars Moriandi. Ars Amandi, you know, Amare, Amor. Ars Amandi is the art of loving, the romantic art, how to transform Eros into divine Eros. In the Middle Ages, though, they talked about Ars Moriandi, the technique. Ars, you know, is the same root as art, right? I mean, it is art, the Latin word for art, Ars Artis. So Ars translates the Greek technike, actually, technique. There were actual manuals written in Latin in the Middle Ages called Ars Moriandi, the technique of dying, how to die. Essentially, they were Roman Catholic books of the dead, analogous to the Tibetan book of the dead or the Egyptian book of the dead. I work a lot with the dying issue. Thanatos is very close because of the nature of our lives. I work a lot with the dying issue. I work a lot with the dying issue because I am very close, because of the nature of my profession. People call me routinely to help them through that process or to help them deal with somebody that's going Let me just say a few things about Ars Moriendi. One of the difficulties is that we're mostly oriented towards Eros for most of our life, towards life, the life-affirming principle that pushes us into existence. We're alienated from the death principle. We don't even know that it is an equal and equally wonderful and equally necessary and equally powerful half of God. We don't even know it. In fact, in many traditions, that half of God is demonized. So we're estranged. According to Sasaki Roshi, that's our main problem. We're lopsided in our connection with God. We're estranged from the contractive side, the limiting side. So we're involved in life, life, life, life, life, life, life, life, life, and then at some point there's a turnaround. It's time to make a relationship with the other side. And that transition is a very difficult one, a very tricky one for people. Because if somebody gets ill and the doctor says you have 90%, 95% of people in your situation die, we don't want to just say, you know, well, you're going to die, you might as well just accept that you're going to die now. That's writing that person off. So how do we approach to somebody who is in this situation the fact that they need to learn to prepare and work for the dying process without just writing them off? Very tricky. I'll tell you how I do it. What I do is I say, let's be honest, you're in a life-threatening situation. That's the vocabulary I use. Not you're going to die, but you're in a life-threatening situation. That means that it's still valid, if it seems appropriate for you, to fight for life. But at least you have to consider now the reality of death in a way that you never considered before, because it's a palpable visage to you. And let me tell you some things about the spiritual dimension of the dying process. So that's how I sort of deal with it with people, so as not to discourage them from attempting to be healed, not to write them off, but also to get them to look, really look at the fact that there is an art of dying and you need to get a momentum going into it. There needs to be preparation. Otherwise, you're going to miss something. What happens is, for so many people, denial, denial, denial, distraction, denial, distraction, denial, distraction, and then it's the last couple days and they don't have a momentum to make optimal use of what they're going through. When I work with somebody who is an extremist, the work is very simple. I'll describe it to you so that you can use it for yourself when your time comes, or you may want to implement these principles in working with other people. It's pretty simple. You know what the job of a midwife is? A midwife doesn't make a baby happen. A midwife understands the birthing process and helps it along. That's called the meiudic art, the art of helping the birth process along. I consider myself in doing this to be a reverse midwife. Same basic process, but I'm helping the death process along by knowing what its elements are and sensitizing the person to go with that. Even if somebody is very sick and fading in and out of consciousness and highly drugged, it's still possible to work quite effectively with them, even over the telephone. I may not see them, but their relatives are holding the phone to their ear and they're on life support system and they're going in and out. But amazingly, one can still facilitate the process, but everything has to be presented very simply. And you have to be very respectful of the fact that the person may only be able to concentrate for five, ten minutes at a time. They have to just rest. So it's not like when I guide people on an online and I've got an hour and a half and I can go into all sorts of minute, complex descriptions of things. It's very different from that. But there's about a half dozen basic questions and they're yes and no questions. They're just yes and no questions. So all the person has to do is nod their head. They don't even have to be able to talk. And a lot of times they can't. Because when you die, you die. Your functionality is stripped from you. I don't care how smart or how strong or for that matter how enlightened. The functionality is stripped from you. The only difference is if you're enlightened, you're not identifying with that functionality that's being taken from you because you've already identified with something that never changes to whatever extent you are enlightened. So all they have to do is nod their head, yes or no. What are the questions? Does it feel like your body wants to go very limp and be just very limp? And if they say yes, then I say go for that. Let your body get really limp and relaxed. Don't do anything. You feel weak, usually they feel very weak. Then does it feel good to just let your body be really limp and loose and totally relaxed? If they say yes, then keep paying attention to that slight pleasant feeling of letting your body be completely limp and loose. And I reinforce that every ten seconds or so or every couple minutes. Very simple words, let your body be just limp and relaxed. Able to do that, maybe they nod their head yes. Does that feel good? Does that feel natural? Yes. If they say no, I don't pursue it. They'll either say yes or no. What is this? Well the body naturally wants to go into equanimity. That littleness, that looseness, that relaxation is the body equanimity. I'll ask the person, does it seem like your mind is empty? You don't have thoughts or the thoughts stop, there's just not much going on there. That's very common when a person is in the dying process. The thoughts stop. Of course not inevitably, some people chatter inside to the end. Therefore, of course, unable to really understand the process. But I'll ask the question. They either say yes or no. They either say that things have gotten really quiet up there or not. If they say no, then I don't pursue it. If they say yes, I say tune into that. Be consciously aware moment by moment that your thought processes become peaceful. The shock to the body, the shock to the brain of dying can turn off the internal dialogue. In fact, tends to turn off the internal dialogue. My job is to just find out if that has happened, sensitize them to the fact that it's happened, and sensitize them to the fact that that may really feel good, and then encourage them to tune into that. If I've got yes on the body and yes on the mind, what's happening? I'm getting their body into equanimity and I'm getting their mind into equanimity. Well, you know the effect of equanimity. Then does it seem like there's any energy or vibrations flowing through you? They'll either say yes or no. And by the way, I should say, parenthetically, these questions are not just questions I ask meditators. I do the same thing with people that have no spiritual background whatsoever, because these are characteristics of the dying process for anybody, whether people are aware of it or not. They'll either say yes or no. Okay, pay attention to that and let it sort of massage you and nurture you. Is that pleasant for you? They'll either say yes or no. They say, no, I don't pursue it. I can't go into detailed work on these things. They're not in a state for that. But if they say yes, then I have them tune into it and I reinforce every couple minutes, pay attention to that energy, enjoy that energy. Sometimes at this point, they'll get a smile on their face, which for the relatives and friends around is big. It's just huge. In fact, one of the most interesting things working with dying people, if it's quote successful, which it's not always quote successful, but when it is successful, the impact on the people around is just phenomenal. It's life changing. Afterwards, some family member will ask for literature on meditation or something like that, just out of the blue. Of course, people realize when you see a loved one die, you identify with that process. You realize that's going to happen to me. And if you see them doing it skillfully, joyously, that's a real eye opener for people. Another question I ask is, are you aware of any light, any bright light? This is of course vividly described in the Tibetan Book of the Dead, the clear light of the void. But I don't use any fancy schmancy expressions like, you know, are you experiencing the clear light of the void? I just say, are you aware of any light? They'll either say yes or no. And then if they say yes and they're present enough, I might determine something of the quality of the light, its brightness, whether it's uniform, whether it's stable, just for me to get an idea of how close to the actual clear light experience they are. And then I'll encourage them to look at the light, enjoy the light, maybe even dive into the light. I may get no on all of the above. I may get no to the body wanting to relax, no to the mind being, you know, peaceful, no to vibrations and energies, might get a no to light. So then I ask my ace in the hole. And if I get a no to that, well, I've done my best. I've exhausted my repertoire of artes moriandi, arts of dying. I say, does it seem like you just want to let go of everything? They'll either say yes or no. If they say yes, then I go with that. Every couple of minutes, just let go of everything, just let go of everything. And that's what I do. And sometimes it works really dramatically, sometimes it works just a little bit, sometimes it doesn't work at all. But that's the nature of the process. But it works enough that I don't approach doing this with trepidation. It would be inappropriate to say it's fun for me, but it is fulfilling. I guess that's the word to use. It's fulfilling to do this. So that's Thanatos. In the literal sense of the word, Thanatos, death. But of course, Thanatos, death, in the sense of human beings dying, is just one of the many masks of contraction, the contractive side of things. Just like Eros is one of the many masks of expansion. So I thought it might be a good thing to talk a little bit about Thanatos and Eros. One last thing apropos of Thanatos in the sense of the flesh and blood experience of a human being dying. We tend to look upon this as a catastrophe. You know literally what the word catastrophe means? Well strophe means a turn in Greek. Strophe is a turning. Kata means down. Catastrophe is a downturn. And it is a term from Greek theater, classical theater of ancient Greece. And catastrophe is a point in the drama where there's a downturn of events. But there's another strophe word that's an interesting one, which you probably have not heard. There's a word epistrophe, E-P-I-S-T-R-O-P-H-E. And this is a term from the philosophy of Platonism, especially in its later form, which is called Neoplatonism, and which had a profound impact on Christianity. And the Neoplatonic philosophy, which also had a profound impact on Kabbalah, Jewish mysticism, sought to understand how things arise from the source and how things return to the source, just as we in meditation, in Buddhist meditation. Basically what I'm teaching you is the paradigm of Zen with the methodology of vipassana. That's sort of what you're getting here actually. The way I'm presenting it to you, we're exploring the process of how things well up and return to the source. But the way you get to that is by first returning to the source. Then you can understand how the source creates over and over again. The return to the source was called epistrophe. Epi means back, so epistrophe is turning back. And then pro-odos, P-R-O-H-O-D-O-S, was the emanation from the source. So they talked about pro-odos kai epistrophe, this coming forth and returning. So the idea is that the catastrophes of our life are an opportunity for epistrophe, is the way I like to look at it. All of this is conceptual. I'm a very conceptual dude. So what I have started to do at the end of retreats is, at least for a few minutes, it's a stretch for me, but a few minutes get out of the prosaic mode and into the poetic mode for a little change of pace to end the retreat. Because poetry expresses these same things, but speaks to a different mode of functioning of our minds. So I'm going to recite a poem for you. Just a couple things to say by way of preface. This poem, it's not a very long one, but it has a couple images that are interesting or might bear some comment. There is a tradition in the West of describing what in Buddhism we call the flow of impermanence, chi expansion, contraction, this kind of thing, of describing it in terms of flame or fire. That's not often done, to my knowledge, in the Eastern cultures, but in the West you find that. It starts with one of the extraordinary individuals, one of the most extraordinary Westerners to ever live, probably, whose name was Heraclitus. If you're interested in such things as very early Western philosophy, way before Socrates, Plato, Aristotle, or any of those people, the earliest of the Greek philosophers are very interesting and they're called Presocratics, Presocratic philosophers. To my mind, Heraclitus sounds out like a colossus among them. He's the first Westerner to have insight into impermanence. He's the one that is supposed to have said, you can't step in the same stream twice. You may have heard that expression. According to him, the basic principle of the universe was something that he called pyrrhos, fire. But by fire, almost everybody has misunderstood him from that time on, and they thought he meant fire, fire. But what he meant was that which is constantly moving and unfixated. It's very evident from the fragments, the Heraclitian fragments, that he was describing the kinds of things that I've been attempting to describe, the dissolution back into the flow, and then what happens when that flow stops. He said that Zeus, the source, God, scatters and gathers, wells up, flames up, and subsides, and is never fixated. He said God is day, God is night, worked with the same kinds of polarities as Sasaki Roshi. Really really interesting person. And he said even when things seem stable, that's just because there's a balance of expansion and contraction. And the metaphor he gave was like a bow that is strung, seems very stable, but that's just because the expansiveness of the bow and the contractiveness of the string cancel each other out. It's just amazing stuff. So Heraclitus described the action of the source as fire or flame, and that's continued in the Western tradition. You can find it in the poetry of Novalis, you can find it in the Jewish mystical tradition. Some of you may know the characteristic gesture of Orthodox prayer, which is sometimes referred to as davening loosely. Why they pray that way is that they're supposed to be like a flame that's blowing without will in the wind of God. So that flame metaphor is there also. So to understand this poem, you need to understand that flame metaphor. When we started this retreat, the very first day I talked about how the retreat was a cocoon that would allow for a safe dissolution and metamorphosis from caterpillar to butterfly. And it wasn't quite complete though, because I forgot to tell you that... I'm looking for a little thing here... That butterfly is just half the way there. What does it mean to become a butterfly? Means that you are very light and insubstantial. So light that you're hardly even there. Some of you have experienced that kind of thinning out of your being occasionally in the city or maybe consistently, maybe consistently as you bob around the world. You become paper thin like a butterfly. But then there's one more step. The butterfly has to become so thin that it disappears back in the source for a while. So I had this whole butterfly metaphor. So after I gave that talk, Nicola said she had been, before the retreat, had been thinking about butterflies and how the retreat was a metamorphosis. And she had bought me this gift of a butterfly. And then it turns out that that's what I ended up talking about. So that was a very nice synchronicity. So I've got a poem for you, Nicola, for you personally. And I'd like you to come here while I recite it to you. But this is not a poem that I wrote. It's a poem that I translated from German. So I'm going to recite it in its original language. Over here, sir? Yes, bit head. Right here. Yes, good. And maybe sort of semi-facing this way towards me. And then after I recite it in German, I hope I can remember it after this big... After this big build-up. Would be a big self-arising if I suddenly... And then I'll give you a rendition in English. And I know people are going to ask, so if you'd like a translation, just call VSI and we can send you one. This is a poem by Johann Wolfgang von Goethe. Natürlich. Natürlich. Goethe. You know, Goethe. I need a break. Because I said, give me a break. It was, of course, an amazing, amazing poet. And it is called Selige Sehnsucht. Sagt es niemand, nur den Weisen, Weil die Menge gleich verhöhnet. Das Lebendige will ich preisen, Das nach Flammentod sich sehnet. In der Liebesnächte kühlung, Die dich zeugt, wo du zeugtest, Überfährst dich fremde Fühlung, Wenn die stille Kerze leuchtet. Nicht mehr bleibest du umfangen In der finsternen Beschadung, Und die Reise neu verlangen Auf zur höheren Begattung. Keine Ferne macht dich schwierig, Troms geflogen und gebart, Und zuletzt des Lichts begehrig, Bist du Schmetterling verbrannt. Und solange du das nicht hast, Dieses Stirb und Werde, Bist du nur ein Triebelgras Auf der dunklen Erde. This is too much. Too much. My father, in the last hour I was with him, that's what he wanted me to read. I mean, I have never talked about this. It's just unbelievable. Then you begin this. I was... Tell it to no one but the wise, For most will mock it right away. The truly living do I prize, Those who seek in flame to die. In the coolness of love's evening, Where you beget and were begotten, You're overcome with strange new feeling, As the silent candle brightens. No longer are you trapped, admired, In the darkened shadowings, But swept away by new desire To a higher love-making. Distance cannot paw your flight, Spellbound through the air you're born, Till at last, mad for the light, You're a butterfly, then gone. And until you know of this, How to grow through death, You're just another troubled guest On the gloomy earth. May I read the best poem I saw, dear? May I? May I?
